summary_points: 1. Constellation Brands' fiscal year 2025 net loss was $81.4 million, a significant decrease from the $3,169.7 million income in fiscal year 2024.
2.  The expected $4 billion in proceeds from the divestiture of its wine brands has been revised down to approximately $900 million by the end of Q1 FY26.
3. A new $4 billion share repurchase program was approved on April 9, 2025, and is expected to be partially funded by divestiture proceeds.
1. Daniel M. Dickinson, a Caterpillar Inc. board member, will not be seeking re-election at the 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders, a decision not stemming from any disagreement with the company.
2.  The filing is an 8-K report filed on April 9th, 2025, reporting on events that occurred on April 7th, 2025.
3. The filing includes information about the departure of a board member and does not report any significant financial statements or material changes to the business.
1. As of March 31, 2025, Invesco Ltd.'s preliminary assets under management (AUM) were $1,844.8 billion, a 2.3% decrease from the previous month.
2. Unfavorable market returns decreased AUM by $60 billion in March 2025, while net long-term inflows totaled $6.5 billion during the same period.
3. Preliminary average total AUM for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, was $1,880.8 billion.

1. Dominion Energy, Inc. and two subsidiaries entered into a $7 billion Sixth Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Agreement, maturing in April 2030 (unless extended), and a $1 billion amendment to their Sustainability Revolving Credit Agreement, extending its maturity to April 2028.
2.  The company's year-over-year borrowing capacity increased significantly, from an unspecified amount in April 2024 to a combined $8 billion in April 2025 across both credit facilities.
3.  Failure to maintain credit ratings from at least two of S&P, Moody's, and Fitch would result in higher interest rates and fees, with the applicable percentages rising to Pricing Level VI.
1. Delta's operating income decreased by $45 million in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024, despite a 2% revenue increase, suggesting rising operating costs.
2.  $4.1 billion in passenger revenue, previously recorded as a liability, was recognized in Q1 2025.
3. Delta's loss on fuel hedge contracts improved significantly in Q1 2025, decreasing from a $96 million loss in Q1 2024 to a $20 million loss.

1. Henry Schein Inc. and KKR Hawaii Aggregator L.P. entered into a Letter Agreement on Voting Commitment on April 7, 2025, modifying certain voting provisions of their existing Strategic Partnership Agreement.

2.  The agreement allows KKR to vote at its discretion on shareholder proposals if both Institutional Shareholder Services and Glass Lewis issue voting recommendations differing from the Board's recommendation (excluding director elections/removals).
3. This agreement, effective April 7, 2025, does not amend other terms of the January 29, 2025 Strategic Partnership Agreement.
1. Walmart's Q1 2026 sales growth is expected to remain within its 3-4% outlook as of April 9, 2025, while annual sales and operating income growth guidance remains unchanged.
2.  Between April 2023 and April 2025, Walmart generated over 5% annual top-line growth and almost 10% adjusted operating income growth.

3. The range of outcomes for Walmart's Q1 2026 operating income growth has widened due to unfavorable category mix, higher casualty claims expense, and planned price investments in response to implemented tariffs.
1. Delta Air Lines reported March quarter 2025 GAAP operating income of $569 million (a 7% decrease year-over-year), and adjusted operating income of $591 million (an 8% decrease year-over-year).
2.  The company reduced planned capacity growth in the second half of 2025 to be flat year-over-year, citing a slower-growth economic environment.

3. Delta projects a June quarter 2025 operating margin of 11% to 14% and earnings per share of $1.70 to $2.30 (non-GAAP measures), but  is not reaffirming its full-year 2025 financial guidance due to economic uncertainty.
1. As of April 8th, 2025, News Corp had repurchased approximately US$658,632,299.06 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On April 8th, 2025, 21,479,361 Class A shares and 10,600,285 Class B shares were repurchased, costing US$436,807,641.38 and US$221,278,379.84 respectively.
3. News Corp's stock repurchase program, announced on April 8th, 2025, intends to continue repurchasing shares of Class A and Class B common stock subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. Host Hotels & Resorts intends to raise up to $600 million through the sale of up to 4,769,549 shares of common stock in two tranches.
2.  Venable LLP issued legal opinions on April 8, 2025, confirming the legality of the stock offering under Maryland law.
3.  As of April 9, 2025, no further details beyond the maximum offering size have been disclosed.
1. On April 7, 2025, Khaled Al Mogharbel announced his resignation as Executive Vice President, Geographies, effective May 1, 2025, after 30 years with Schlumberger Limited.
2.  Al Mogharbel will receive 75% of his current base salary annually for three years as an advisor to the CEO, plus continued benefits and a prorated 2025 incentive award.
3.  The agreement with Al Mogharbel includes three-year non-competition and non-solicitation clauses, with penalties for breach including cessation of payments and cancellation of equity awards.
1. FactSet Research Systems Inc. secured a $1.5 billion credit agreement on April 8, 2025, replacing their 2022 agreement.
2.  The agreement includes a leverage ratio covenant of 3.75:1.00, potentially rising to 4.25:1.00 under specific acquisition conditions.
3.  The new credit facility matures on April 8, 2030.

1. Anne T. Madden, Honeywell International Inc.'s Senior Vice President and General Counsel, is transitioning to a newly created position, Senior Vice President, Portfolio Transformation and Senior Advisor, effective May 5, 2025, with a base salary of $750,000 and a target annual long-term incentive award of $2,000,000.
2.  Su Ping Lu will succeed Ms. Madden as Senior Vice President and General Counsel, effective May 5, 2025.

3.  Ms. Madden's compensation in her new role will include an annual base salary of $750,000, a target annual incentive of 100% of base salary, and annual long-term incentive awards with a target value of $2,000,000.
1. Procter & Gamble's Board of Directors declared a 5% increase to their quarterly dividend on April 8th, 2025, to $1.0568 per share, payable on or after May 15th, 2025.
2.  Procter & Gamble has paid a dividend for 135 consecutive years and increased it for 69 consecutive years.
3. No specific future impacts or risks were identified in this section of the filing.
